MainClaim.text: Heidegger's conception of the political sphere in GA94 is characterized by an occlusion, a suppression of the political by the ontological.

Occlusion of the political.text: The political is cast primarily as a threat, leading Heidegger to be reluctant to engage with its categories and questions.

Ontological dominance.text: Philosophy and ontology frame the discourse in GA94, with the political being used only as a distribution channel for the ontological.

Heidegger's response to the threat of th.text: Heidegger employs three strategies to deal with the threat of the political: disengagement, aggression, and co-option.

Heidegger's view of the political.text: The political is characterized as a threat to philosophy and ontology in GA94.

Suppression of the political.text: Heidegger presides over an occlusion or suppression of the political in GA94.

Heidegger's conception of the political.text: Heidegger's conception of the political in GA94 is characterized by a negative view of the public sphere.

Heidegger's political thought.text: Heidegger's political thought is non-political in the sense that it raises political issues only to thematize them using values and concepts drawn from ontology.

Heidegger's treatment of authenticity.text: Heidegger's treatment of authenticity exemplifies a process whereby ethical norms are gradually reinterpreted as ontological norms.

Value of authenticity.text: Authenticity is valuable because it enables a philosophy properly orientated towards Being.

Heidegger's view of the relationship bet.text: Heidegger's view of the relationship between ontology and politics is one of ontological dominance.
Heidegger's view of the relationship between ontology and ethics is one of ontological dominance.
